title: Advent Calendars For Web Designers And Developers (December 2021 Edition)
content:
Once again, the web community has been busy with creating some fantastic advent calendars this year. As you‚Äôll see, each and every one of these calendars are sure to cater for a daily dose of web design and development goodness with stellar articles, inspiring experiments, and even puzzles to solve.

It doesn‚Äôt really matter if you‚Äôre a front-end dev, UX designer or content strategist, we‚Äôre certain you‚Äôll find at least something to inspire you for the upcoming year. Use this month of December as a time to slow down, and your time to reflect and plan ahead ‚Äî you won‚Äôt regret it.

Advent of JavaScript

If you sign up to the Advent of JavaScript, you‚Äôll be getting an email every day that outlined a JavaScript challenge. Each of the given challenges include all of the HTML and CSS you need to get started, allowing you to focus on the JavaScript. You‚Äôll also receive a brief on how to get started, ways to push yourself, and steps to help you get started. You can get the challenges for free (or pay for the solutions).

  • James Q. Quick on Twitter

Advent of CSS

For folks who‚Äôre more into CSS, there‚Äôs the Advent of CSS where you can sign up for a daily email outlining a CSS challenge that includes all the assets you need to get started ‚Äî including a Figma design file. (If you don‚Äôt have a Figma account, don‚Äôt worry, it‚Äôs free.) Before accepting this challenge, you really should know basic HTML and CSS.

  • Amy Dutton on Twitter

JVM Programming Advent Calendar

The Java Advent 2021 is here! To make the advent season even sweeter for JVM enthusiasts, there will be a new article about JVM-related topic everyday. The project started in 2012 with the idea of providing technical content during the Christmas Advent period, so keep looking for nice things under the Java Christmas tree! üéÑ

  • RSS Feed
  • @JavaAdvent on Twitter

Advent of Code

If you prefer a puzzle over an article, take a look at Advent of Code. Created by Eric Wastl, this is an advent calendar of small programming puzzles for a variety of skill sets and skill levels that can be solved in any programming language you like. You don‚Äôt need a computer science background to participate ‚Äî just a little programming knowledge and some problem solving skills will get you pretty far. Go ahead and give it a go!

  • #AdventOfCode on Twitter
  • @ericwastl on Twitter

Perl 6/Raku Advent Calendar

Back in October of 2019, ‚ÄúPerl 6‚Äù was renamed to ‚ÄúRaku‚Äù. It‚Äôs the 6th year since (what was then called) Perl 6 was released, and the 13th year in a row for this Raku Advent calendar. Stay tuned for lots of articles on metaprogramming, applications, useful Raku modules, programming techniques, guides on how to work with Raku inside containers, and even how to migrate from good ol‚Äô Perl.

  • RSS Feed

24 Pull Requests

24 Pull Requests is a yearly initiative to encourage contributors around the world to send 24 pull requests between December 1st and December 24th. The project is available in twenty languages, and encourages all kinds of contributions to open-source projects ‚Äî including non-pull-request contributions. There‚Äôs a new contribution form on the site that allows you to record the contributions you‚Äôve made each day that wouldn‚Äôt usually make sense as a pull request. Join in!

  • ‚Äú24 Pull Requests‚Äù on GitHub
  • @24PullRequests on Twitter

HTMHell Advent Calendar

If you‚Äôre already familiar with the HTMHell website, then you can guess how interesting its advent calendar is going to get! Take a peek behind each door of the HTMHell calendar where you‚Äôll find an article, talk or tool that focuses on HTML. To be fair, HTMHell isn‚Äôt just about bad practices ‚Äî Manuel also shares good practices and useful HTML tips and tricks. üî•

  • @htm_hell on Twitter
  • Manuel Matuzoviƒá on Twitter
  • ‚ÄúHTML Tips & Tricks‚Äù RSS Feed

PerfPlanet Calendar

An advent calendar that has been publishing since 2009 is back again. Good ol‚Äô PerfPlanet is back for another season with all things speed and web performance. Anyone is welcome to contribute to the calendar, so do feel free to reach out with a topic or tool you‚Äôre passionate about, or a technique you‚Äôd like to teach and tell the web performance community about.

  • Stoyan Stefanov on Twitter
  • Perfplanet calendar‚Äôs oldies but goodies

C# Advent Calendar

It‚Äôs time for the fifth annual C# advent calendar that will feature two pieces of content every day. Anyone can contribute by sharing their blog posts, videos, articles or podcast episodes dedicated to C# development. In case all of the spots are already claimed, you can always sign up to be a substitute author. Rock on! üé∏

  • #csadvent on Twitter
  • @mgroves on Twitter

Inclusive Design 24

The good folks at Inclusive Design 24 are sharing their favorite talks from previous years of the good ol‚Äô #id24 online-only conferences while counting down the days until the New Year. All videos have even been manually re-captioned, just so they‚Äôre all at their best.

  • @id24conf on Twitter

Lean UXMas

Lean UXMas has been publishing each advent since 2014 and is a collection of the most popular articles from this year‚Äôs Agile and Lean UX latest news. If you find yourself impatiently waiting for the next article to be posted, you can always check out the previous advent calendars smashing the year in the base URL, or simply search for them below the website‚Äôs header.

  • RSS Feed
  • @LeanUXmas on Twitter

Code Security Advent Calendar

If you‚Äôre up for a challenge that involves spotting security vulnerabilities, then the Code Security Advent Calendar is just the right one for you. Every day, there will be a code security puzzle and/or riddle announced on Twitter to which you‚Äôre welcome to join and share with your friends to discuss solutions together. The most active players with the best solutions will be contacted to receive a cool swag pack. üéÅ

  • @SonarSource on Twitter

Advent of Cyber

Security can be a daunting field. With Advent of Cyber, you can get started with Cyber Security by learning the basics and completing a new, beginner friendly security exercise every day. For each task you get correct, you get a raffle ticket and on the 26th December, meaning the more questions you answer, the more chance you have of winning. Every day you complete a challenge, you get entered into another prize draw for the chance to win a mini-prize. So, what are you waiting for?

  • TryHackMe on Twitter
  • John Hammond on Twitter

24 Days In December

‚ÄúPHP is not just a language. PHP is a group of people, a community of developers who build things for the web. The PHPamily spans the globe, and while we might not always agree or get along, we have one thing in common, we‚Äôre passionate about what we do.‚Äù Jonathan Bossenger hits the nail right on the head as he welcomes everyone to participate in the 6th edition of 24 Days in December. We‚Äôre all look forward to hearing your personal journey and stories with PHP! üåà

  • RSS Feed
  • @24DaysInDec on Twitter

Designcember

As a celebration of web design, the good folks at web.dev are dropping a UI development treat for you every day with their brilliant Designcember advent calendar. Built with CSS container queries and the new CQ Polyfill, it‚Äôs full of little details to explore! Try interacting with the windows, resizing your browser, or clicking on the button at the top right to toggle between dark and light mode. Why not play along and create your own CQ demo?

  • #Designcember on Twitter
  • @ChromiumDev on Twitter

Umbraco Christmas Calendar

It‚Äôs the 10th year of 24 Days In Umbraco and it‚Äôs time to learn more about Umbraco (otherwise known as the ‚ÄòFriendly CMS‚Äô). If you‚Äôre interested in it but not sure where to start, you can always check out the articles by tag(s) and find the answers to your questions. The calendar was first started back in 2012 so there‚Äôs plenty of content to sift through.

  • @24daysinumbraco on Twitter

Festive Tech Calendar 2021

With over 2K subscribers on YouTube, the Festive Tech Calendar is back at it again this year with videos from different communities and people around the globe. As you‚Äôll see, you‚Äôll quickly be able to find an entire collection of videos from all of the previous years, and topics as well as the diversity of speakers both don‚Äôt fall short indeed. By the communities, for the communities indeed.

  • ‚ÄúFestive Tech Calendar‚Äù on YoutTube
  • #FestiveTechCalendar2021 on Twitter
  • @CloudFamily on Twitter

SysAdvent

SysAdvent is back this year! With the goals of sharing, openness and mentoring, you‚Äôre in for some great articles about systems administration topics written by fellow sysadmins. Tune in each day for an article that explores the wide range of topics in system administration.

  • RSS Feed
  • @SysAdvent on Twitter

IT Security Advent Calendar

‚ÄúDon't store sensitive data in the cloud; keep it entirely disconnected from the web.‚Äù Yup, that‚Äôs the credo delivered in the first advent door of the good ol‚Äô IT Security Advent Calendar this year. Counting down to Christmas, this calendar is dedicated to sharing a new tip for protecting your devices, networks, and data each day.

  • @Infowebica on Twitter

Bekk Christmas

This year‚Äôs Bekk Christmas features opinion pieces, tutorials, podcasts, deep dives and lots of other formats. Pick the ones that seem interesting to you, and consume them whenever you like. It‚Äôs worth digging through the archives (see e.g. 2020) ‚Äî there‚Äôs a golden gem hidden in each one of them!

  • Bekk on Twitter
  • Kristofer Giltvedt Selbekk on Twitter



It‚Äôs nice to find some calendars in languages other than English, too! Here are a few we stumbled upon:

24 Jours De Web (French)

24 Jours De Web is a lovely French calendar which first appeared back in 2012, and has been continuing the lovely tradition of online advent calendars ever since. 24 authors come together each year and publish an article on UX, accessibility, privacy, and other topics related to the good ol‚Äô web.

  • RSS Feed
  • @24joursdeweb on Twitter

SELFHTML Adventskalender (German)

This year‚Äôs SELFHTML Adventskalender is dedicated to accessibility ‚Äî a topic that concerns everyone. Why? Because accessibility is good for all of us. Accessible websites are simply better websites. At the end of the day, everyone in the world hits a large key faster and more reliably than a small key. To all the German-speaking developers out there, you‚Äôll understand why it‚Äôs important to include accessibility as much as possible. Also, make sure to bookmark the SELFHTML wiki so you can have the latest documentations and tutorials at hand.

  • RSS Feed
  • @SELFHTML on Twitter

adventJS (Spanish)

Fancy more JavaScript challenges every day? Well, Miguel √Ångel Dur√°n has your back with adventJS ‚Äî an advent calendar that started back in 2015. The programming challenges are all in Spanish, and are meant to be solved with JavaScript only. Don‚Äôt forget to participate and share your solutions on Twitter!

  • #adventjs on Twitter

Kodekalender (Norwegian)

Knowit is one of the Nordic region's leading consulting companies. They have once again brought their Norwegian calendar to life, and it is just the kind of holiday calendar for those of you who love programming. Behind each hatch hides a task you have to answer in the form of a simple text string or a number. The hatches vary in degree of difficulty and design, but common to all is that they are best suited for solving with code. Solve as many slots as possible to increase your chances of winning! Good luck!

  • @knowitnorge on Twitter

WEB„Ç¢„ÇØ„Çª„Ç∑„Éì„É™„ÉÜ„Ç£ Advent Calendar (Japanese)

This Japanese advent calendar has been running since 2013 and is moderated by @hokaccha. Its focus lies on web accessibility, with a new author exploring a topic each day ‚Äî from web accessibility to all the different types of programming languages you may want to explore for your projects. Once logged in, you can save a spot on the calendar and have your article or work published on that particular day.


Do you happen to know any other advent calendars that have been created in languages other than in English? Please do feel free to reach out to me on Twitter and I‚Äôll be sure to add them to this list. üôå
Oldies But Goodies

Christmas Experiments (2018)

Christmas Experiments started back in 2012, with the goal to deliver great experiments and highlight top web creative as well as newcomers. It was a pretty cool WebGL advent calendar that featured a daily new experiment that was quite obviously made with love by digital artists. Unfortunately, it did not continue after the 2018 edition.

  • @christmasxp on Twitter

24 Accessibility (2019)

An advent calendar we surely miss is the 24 Accessibility. The site hasn‚Äôt had a new article since 2019, but still offers a good resource of articles on all subjects related to digital accessibility. Whether you are new to accessibility or a veteran, a developer, designer, user experience professional, quality assurance analyst or project manager, you‚Äôll find an article of interest during the run of the series.

  • RSS Feed
  • @24accessibility on Twitter

It‚Äôs A Shape Christmas (2019)

It‚Äôs A Shape Christmas is a digital calendar that counts down to Christmas and reveals a bespoke illustration each day themed around four different shapes (Square, Triangle, Circle and Hexagon) and Christmas. The project was started in 2011 by a UK design agency called Made by Shape. The website still showcases some of the best from the previous seasons. I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôll agree: they‚Äôre all just too good not to be shared! ‚ú®

  • @shapechristmas on Twitter

24 Ways (2019)

First initiated by Drew McLellan, 24 ways started out as a simple website that published a new tip or trick each day leading readers through December up until Christmas. It launched in 2005 and still has all of the calendars available online. Unfortunately, the last one was published in 2019 and will be taking a well-earned break after that year‚Äôs ‚Äúfinal countdown‚Äù.

  • RSS Feed
  • @24ways on Twitter

Perl Advent (2020)

The Perl Advent started back in 2000 and is perhaps the longest running web advent calendar that many know of. You‚Äôll find insightful articles written by diverse author submissions from all types of Perl programming levels. A different Perl module will be featured each day for the twenty four days of advent, and an extra module on Christmas day. Make sure to go through the previous Perl advent calendars ‚Äî it‚Äôs worth it.

  • RSS Feed
  • Mark Fowler‚Äôs website

PWAdvent (2020)

PWAdvent is a nice advent calendar for everyone who‚Äôs excited about the web platform and Progressive Web Apps, of course. Take a look at all the great stuff the web has to offer in last year‚Äôs calendar, in which a new progressive browser feature was introduced every day by Nico Martin himself and others.

A11y Advent Calendar (2020)

Heydon Pickering once said, ‚ÄúAccessibility is not about doing more work but about doing the right work.‚Äù Last year, Kitty Giraudel decided to publish an accessibility tip a day in their very own #A11yAdvent. Some of the tips are probably common knowledge for many, yet each of the posts cover so many of the important aspects of accessibility that will still hold true for years to come.

  • RSS Feed
  • Kitty Giraudel on Twitter

Last But Not Least...

Of course, we wanted to join in the fun ourselves and brought our very own #SmashingAdvent to life! As you already probably know, the Smashing team has been organizing conferences and events since 2012, so there are plenty of gems to shine the spotlight on. Do give @SmashingConf a follow on Twitter where we‚Äôll be sharing our favorite talks and interviews with speakers from all over the globe.

On behalf of the entire Smashing team, we‚Äôd like to say thank you to each and every one involved in these projects ‚Äî we see you! The communities in our web industry wouldn‚Äôt be able to learn so much and thrive if it wasn‚Äôt for your time, hard work and dedication. We all sincerely and truly appreciate each and every one of you. üôè

And of course, if there‚Äôs a calendar that isn‚Äôt mentioned here, please do post it in comments section below.
